0.1 Series Overview

This series follows FastAI’s practical, top-down approach to learning data science. Instead of starting with theory, we’ll begin with practical applications and gradually dive deeper into the underlying concepts.

0.1.1 Learning Philosophy

  • Start with the practical: We begin with working code and real applications
  • Spiral learning: Revisit concepts multiple times with increasing depth
  • Learn by doing: Each post includes hands-on notebooks and exercises

0.1.2 Posts in this Series

  1. Getting Started with Data Science
    • Setting up your environment
    • Your first end-to-end project
  2. Data Exploration and Visualization
    • Practical EDA techniques
    • Creating impactful visualizations
  3. Feature Engineering and Selection
    • Transforming data for better models
    • Selecting the most important features
  4. Model Selection and Training
    • Choosing the right model
    • Training best practices
  5. Model Evaluation and Interpretation
    • Understanding model performance
    • Interpreting model decisions
  6. Deployment and Monitoring
    • Taking models to production
    • Monitoring and maintaining models

0.2 Prerequisites

  • Basic Python knowledge
  • Familiarity with Jupyter notebooks
  • Understanding of basic statistics (we’ll review as needed)

0.3 Tools We’ll Use

  • PyTorch for deep learning
  • Pandas for data manipulation
  • Scikit-learn for traditional ML
  • FastAI for rapid prototyping

0.4 Getting Help

  • Use the comments section below each post
  • Check the GitHub repository for code
  • Join our discussion forum (coming soon)
Note

This series is continuously updated with new content and improvements based on reader feedback.

## Series Overview

This series follows FastAI's practical, top-down approach to learning data science. Instead of starting with theory, we'll begin with practical applications and gradually dive deeper into the underlying concepts.

### Learning Philosophy

- **Start with the practical**: We begin with working code and real applications
- **Spiral learning**: Revisit concepts multiple times with increasing depth
- **Learn by doing**: Each post includes hands-on notebooks and exercises

### Posts in this Series

1. [Getting Started with Data Science](../data-science-steps-to-follow-part01/index.qmd)
   - Setting up your environment
   - Your first end-to-end project
   
2. [Data Exploration and Visualization](../data-science-steps-to-follow-part02/index.qmd)
   - Practical EDA techniques
   - Creating impactful visualizations
   
3. [Feature Engineering and Selection](../data-science-steps-to-follow-part03/index.qmd)
   - Transforming data for better models
   - Selecting the most important features
   
4. [Model Selection and Training](../data-science-steps-to-follow-part04/index.qmd)
   - Choosing the right model
   - Training best practices
   
5. [Model Evaluation and Interpretation](../data-science-steps-to-follow-part05/index.qmd)
   - Understanding model performance
   - Interpreting model decisions
   
6. [Deployment and Monitoring](../data-science-steps-to-follow-part06/index.qmd)
   - Taking models to production
   - Monitoring and maintaining models

## Prerequisites

- Basic Python knowledge
- Familiarity with Jupyter notebooks
- Understanding of basic statistics (we'll review as needed)

## Tools We'll Use

- PyTorch for deep learning
- Pandas for data manipulation
- Scikit-learn for traditional ML
- FastAI for rapid prototyping

## Getting Help

- Use the comments section below each post
- Check the [GitHub repository](https://github.com/yourusername/quarto_blog_hasan) for code
- Join our discussion forum (coming soon)

:::{.callout-note}
This series is continuously updated with new content and improvements based on reader feedback.
:::
